course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Abnormal Psychology
course.description: Abnormal psychology is the scientific study of psychopathology and abnormal behavior. This course introduces theories, research methods, and the most updated research findings in the field of abnormal psychology. Students will be introduced to various types of psychological disorders, such as mood disorders, schizophrenia, personality disorders, somatoform disorders, sex-related disorders, etc. They will also learn about the diagnosis, causes, maintenance, and treatment of major psychological disorders from an integrative perspective.
course.prerequisites: SOSC 1960 OR SOSC 1980

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content:
The course first introduces us with the general framework and tools to understand abnormality, including different dimensions of psychological disorders, assessment, and diagnostic tools. It then looks into different psychological disorders one by one. Kinda dull at first but becomes interesting once different psychological disorders are introduced.

She shows a few videos in class to demonstrate the feelings of the patients suffering these psychological disorders and how they look like. She also engages us with class discussion questions, usually on issues that are not that trivial and require a lil bit of thinking. But don't worry - she will go over the answers thoroughly at the end.

reviews.comment_workload:
Quizzes comprise of multiple choice questions that are actually quite tricky and require a thorough understanding of details. Textbook reading is not absolutely required but you will need to go through the relevant chapters in the textbook if you really want to ace the course. Beatrice explicitly said that quite a few questions in the quizzes would be based on the textbook materials not mentioned in class.

The group project basically lets us explore a psychological disorder not covered in class and we are required to pick a celebrity/case vignette and explore the etiology, the person's symptoms and the treatment applying the multipath model, i.e. we have to discuss the disorder from the biological, the psychological, the social, and the sociocultural dimensions. Then we need to deliver a 10-minute presentation in class elaborating on our findings and write individually a 600-word essay on the one treatment approach of the disorder. The most challenging part is that you have to be absolutely concise due to the time and word limits. Explaining all these things in a neat manner in merely 10 minutes is not that easy.

The class participation marks are based on the submission of class discussion answers. Just make sure you don't skip all the classes and you will be fine. FYI she took attendance 7 times this semester.

reviews.author: fergus
reviews.title: Rather simple course with reasonable amount of workload
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting, includes a broad scope of mental disorder, I personally find the professor explained them just thorough enough to not make us feel overwhelmed by it while at the same time you do learn a lot about the diseases.
reviews.comment_teaching: Does lots of explaining based on the powerpoints. She will also show videos in-class that will show up in the exams so you should attend class.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mean is pretty high in both mid term and final so you have to make sure you studied the material thoroughly.
The exams are mostly based on your understanding of the course rather than memorisation, since the exam format is in MC.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very acceptable imo. Presentation and individual report based on your presentation.

reviews.author: Krispy
reviews.comment_content:
The course focuses on the major mental disorders in the DSM V.  Topics include schizophrenia, depression, ADHD, phobias, DID, bi-polar disorders etc. You will learn about the causes of each disorder, the symptoms, and treatment.

As this is abnormal psychology, you'll be learning some biological terms related to the causes of certain disorders. So be prepared to memorise some biological terms.

The cases & videos are rather interesting though! Dr Lai usually gives a few cases for each disorder and she'll show videos of the patients with that particular disorder.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Lai's classes are more or less the same. I've taken her SOSC1980 course before so I was familiar with her teaching style.

She usually reads off her slides, but will purposely leave some parts out of the notes, so you have to pay attention to get the missing stuff! She might come off as slightly boring at times, but then again, if you're genuinely interested in the subject, you'll be able to pay attention.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is rather fair. But its difficult to get a good grade. I've managed to get above the mean for both tests. I think my group did alright for the group project, but since the class size is small, and there were only 4 groups in total, it really skewed the grade curve.

I ended up with a B range grade (I forgot if its B+/B/B-). So I guess if you want a good grade, you really have to be the best. Her quizzes are in MCQ form so make sure you try to score in those!
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. You only have to do a group project, which is a presentation at the end of the course. And then a 600 word individual essay on your group project.
